question: : My recent Lipid profile came back with Total Cholesterol = 194, HDL = 61,: LDL = 76 and Triglycerides = 287.: At the time, no blood suger test was perfomed due to my regular monitoring: of blood glucose (two hours post meals, readings generally average 125: and then begin to reduce).: There is Type II diabetes in my family (mother and her sisters and their father).: Would you recommend a formal blood glucose test done?  Would high: triglycerides suppress the results for the glucose or other lipids?: Are the high triglycerides elevating my heart risk factor?: I am a 42 year old female; non smoker; light drinker (one glass wine/week); overweight, but otherwise in good health.: Thank you for your response.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Dear Jessica A.:You should definitely be tested for diabetes.  As a first step, you should have a blood glucose checked after an overnight fast.  If you are found to have diabetes, in addition to altering your diet, I would recommend weight loss.  Just a few pounds can make a lot of difference in Type 2 diabetics.Your level of triglycerides would not affect any of the other tests.  If the triglycerides were checked after a meal, that would raise their level.  Triglycerides are usually measured after an overnight fast.  Alcohol consumption can also raise triglyceride levels.Whether elevated triglycerides are a risk factor for cardiac disease is widely debated.  Diabetes is a strong risk factor for heart disease, and diabetics often have elevated triglycerides.  Elevated triglycerides with an associated low HDL [you do not have this problem] can increase the risk of heart disease.  No one knows for sure  whether  isolated elevation of triglycerides of the modest degree you have is an independent risk factor for heart disease.  I would be more concerned about your genetic tendency towards diabetes.If you wish to be evaluated here at the Cleveland Clinic, please call 1-800-CCF-CARE for an appointment with a preventive cardiologist.  Information provided in the Heart Forum is for general purposes only.  Specific diagnoses and therapies can only be provided by your doctor.
title: Elevated Triglycerides
